natural problem: Henry's little brother has $8$ identical stickers and $4$ identical sheets of paper. How many ways are there for him to put all of the stickers on the sheets of paper, if only the number of stickers on each sheet matters?
natural solution: Since only the number of stickers on the sheets matters, we can list the possibilities systematically:  \begin{align} & 8-0-0-0 \\ & 7-1-0-0 \\ & 6-2-0-0 \\ & 6-1-1-0 \\ & 5-3-0-0 \\ & 5-2-1-0 \\ & 5-1-1-1 \\
& 4-4-0-0 \\ & 4-3-1-0 \\ & 4-2-2-0 \\ & 4-2-1-1 \\ & 3-3-2-0 \\ & 3-3-1-1 \\ & 3-2-2-1 \\ & 2-2-2-2 \end{align} There are $\boxed{15}$ possible arrangements of stickers on sheets of paper.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes stickers sheets :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>stickers sheets. ways stickers sheets = (stickers + sheets - 1) choose (sheets - 1)"
shows  "ways 8 4 = 15"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Henry's little brother has $8$ identical stickers and $4$ identical sheets of paper. How many ways are there for him to put all of the stickers on the sheets of paper, if only the number of stickers on each sheet matters? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Since only the number of stickers on the sheets matters, we can list the possibilities systematically:  \begin{align} & 8-0-0-0 \\ & 7-1-0-0 \\ & 6-2-0-0 \\ & 6-1-1-0 \\ & 5-3-0-0 \\ & 5-2-1-0 \\ & 5-1-1-1 \\
 & 4-4-0-0 \\ & 4-3-1-0 \\ & 4-2-2-0 \\ & 4-2-1-1 \\ & 3-3-2-0 \\ & 3-3-1-1 \\ & 3-2-2-1 \\ & 2-2-2-2 \end{align} There are $\boxed{15}$ possible arrangements of stickers on sheets of paper.
 *)

theorem
fixes stickers sheets :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>stickers sheets. ways stickers sheets = (stickers + sheets - 1) choose (sheets - 1)"
shows  "ways 8 4 = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A person has 8 stickers and 4 sheets. They want to distribute the stickers among the sheets. How many ways can they do this? The final answer is 15 ways.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (stickers + sheets - 1) choose (sheets - 1)"
shows  "ways = 15"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Henry's little brother has $8$ identical stickers and $4$ identical sheets of paper. How many ways are there for him to put all of the stickers on the sheets of paper, if only the number of stickers on each sheet matters? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Since only the number of stickers on the sheets matters, we can list the possibilities systematically:  \begin{align} & 8-0-0-0 \\ & 7-1-0-0 \\ & 6-2-0-0 \\ & 6-1-1-0 \\ & 5-3-0-0 \\ & 5-2-1-0 \\ & 5-1-1-1 \\
 & 4-4-0-0 \\ & 4-3-1-0 \\ & 4-2-2-0 \\ & 4-2-1-1 \\ & 3-3-2-0 \\ & 3-3-1-1 \\ & 3-2-2-1 \\ & 2-2-2-2 \end{align} There are $\boxed{15}$ possible arrangements of stickers on sheets of paper.
 *)

theorem
fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (stickers + sheets - 1) choose (sheets - 1)"
shows  "ways = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 8 stickers and 4 sheets. In how many ways can the stickers be distributed among the sheets, assuming that each sheet can hold any number of stickers? The final answer is 15 ways.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (n + r - 1) choose (r - 1)"
and h3 : "n = stickers"
and h4 : "r = sheets"
shows  "ways = 15"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Henry's little brother has $8$ identical stickers and $4$ identical sheets of paper. How many ways are there for him to put all of the stickers on the sheets of paper, if only the number of stickers on each sheet matters? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Since only the number of stickers on the sheets matters, we can list the possibilities systematically:  \begin{align} & 8-0-0-0 \\ & 7-1-0-0 \\ & 6-2-0-0 \\ & 6-1-1-0 \\ & 5-3-0-0 \\ & 5-2-1-0 \\ & 5-1-1-1 \\
 & 4-4-0-0 \\ & 4-3-1-0 \\ & 4-2-2-0 \\ & 4-2-1-1 \\ & 3-3-2-0 \\ & 3-3-1-1 \\ & 3-2-2-1 \\ & 2-2-2-2 \end{align} There are $\boxed{15}$ possible arrangements of stickers on sheets of paper.
 *)

theorem
fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (n + r - 1) choose (r - 1)"
and h3 : "n = stickers"
and h4 : "r = sheets"
shows  "ways = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A teacher has 8 stickers and 4 sheets. In how many different ways can she distribute the stickers among the sheets? The final answer is 15 ways.

a_6.formal problem:

fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (stickers + sheets - 1) choose (sheets - 1)"
shows  "ways = 15"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Henry's little brother has $8$ identical stickers and $4$ identical sheets of paper. How many ways are there for him to put all of the stickers on the sheets of paper, if only the number of stickers on each sheet matters? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Since only the number of stickers on the sheets matters, we can list the possibilities systematically:  \begin{align} & 8-0-0-0 \\ & 7-1-0-0 \\ & 6-2-0-0 \\ & 6-1-1-0 \\ & 5-3-0-0 \\ & 5-2-1-0 \\ & 5-1-1-1 \\
 & 4-4-0-0 \\ & 4-3-1-0 \\ & 4-2-2-0 \\ & 4-2-1-1 \\ & 3-3-2-0 \\ & 3-3-1-1 \\ & 3-2-2-1 \\ & 2-2-2-2 \end{align} There are $\boxed{15}$ possible arrangements of stickers on sheets of paper.

and h2 : "ways = (stickers + sheets - 1) choose (sheets - 1)"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: You have 8 stickers and 4 sheets. In how many ways can you distribute the stickers among the sheets? The final answer is 15 ways.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..sheets}. binomial (stickers + i - 1) (sheets - 1))"
shows  "ways = 15"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Henry's little brother has $8$ identical stickers and $4$ identical sheets of paper. How many ways are there for him to put all of the stickers on the sheets of paper, if only the number of stickers on each sheet matters? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Since only the number of stickers on the sheets matters, we can list the possibilities systematically:  \begin{align} & 8-0-0-0 \\ & 7-1-0-0 \\ & 6-2-0-0 \\ & 6-1-1-0 \\ & 5-3-0-0 \\ & 5-2-1-0 \\ & 5-1-1-1 \\
 & 4-4-0-0 \\ & 4-3-1-0 \\ & 4-2-2-0 \\ & 4-2-1-1 \\ & 3-3-2-0 \\ & 3-3-1-1 \\ & 3-2-2-1 \\ & 2-2-2-2 \end{align} There are $\boxed{15}$ possible arrangements of stickers on sheets of paper.
 *)

theorem
fixes stickers sheets ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "stickers = 8"
and h1 : "sheets = 4"
and h2 : "ways = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..sheets}. binomial (stickers + i - 1) (sheets - 1))"
shows  "ways = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: You have 8 stickers and 4 sheets. In how many ways can you distribute the stickers among the sheets, if the stickers are indistinguishable and the order of the sheets matters? The final answer is 15.
